name: Push-ups
intro: Push-ups are a bodyweight exercise that involve lowering and raising the body using the arms, chest, and core muscles
steps: Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart and your feet hip-width apart.
Lower your body by bending your elbows until your chest touches the ground.
Push your body back up to the starting position.
Keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the exercise.
Avoid locking your elbows at the top of the movement.
If you're a beginner, start with modified pushups by keeping your knees on the ground
precautions: Avoid arching your back or sagging your hips during the exercise, as this can put unnecessary strain on your lower back.
Keep your elbows close to your body to avoid putting excessive pressure on your shoulders.

name: Bicep curls
intro: Bicep curls are an isolation exercise that target the biceps muscles, involving lifting weights in a controlled motion. Regularly performing these exercises can help improve upper body strength and muscle definition
steps: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing up.
Slowly lift the weights towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.
Pause briefly at the top of the movement and then lower the weights back down to the starting position.
Keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the exercise.
Avoid swinging your arms or using momentum to lift the weights.
If you're a beginner, start with lighter weights and focus on proper form
precautions: Don't lift weights that are too heavy for you, as this can lead to injury.
Keep your wrists in a neutral position to avoid straining them.
Avoid jerking or swinging the weights, as this can cause you to lose control of the exercise and potentially injure yourself

name: pull-ups
intro: Pull-ups are a strength exercise that involve lifting the body by pulling up on a bar, targeting the back, biceps, and shoulders
steps: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing up.
Slowly lift the weights towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.
Pause briefly at the top of the movement and then lower the weights back down to the starting position.
Keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the exercise.
Avoid swinging your arms or using momentum to lift the weights.
If you're a beginner, start with lighter weights and focus on proper form
precautions: If you have a history of shoulder injuries or pain, consult with a doctor before attempting pullups.
Don't use a grip that is too wide, as this can put excessive strain on your shoulders and wrists.
If you're unable to complete a full pullup, don't force it. Instead, start with a modified version of the exercise or use an assistive device.
